articles.title: This tiny spacecraft could race to a black hole and rewrite physics
articles.summary: A visionary plan proposes sending a paperclip-sized spacecraft, powered by Earth-based lasers, to a nearby black hole within a century. Led by astrophysicist Cosimo Bambi, the mission would test the limits of general relativity and explore the mysteries of event horizons. While current technology can t yet achieve it, advancements in nanocraft design, laser propulsion, and black hole detection could make the journey possible within decades, potentially rewriting the laws of physics as we know them.
articles.content:
It sounds like science fiction: a spacecraft, no heavier than a paperclip, propelled by a laser beam and hurtling through space at the speed of light toward a black hole, on a mission to probe the very fabric of space and time and test the laws of physics. But to astrophysicist and black hole expert Cosimo Bambi, the idea is not so far-fetched.

Reporting in the Cell Press journal iScience, Bambi outlines the blueprint for turning this interstellar voyage to a black hole into a reality. If successful, this century-long mission could return data from nearby black holes that completely alter our understanding of general relativity and the rules of physics.

"We don't have the technology now," says author Cosimo Bambi of Fudan University in China. "But in 20 or 30 years, we might."

The mission hinges on two key challenges -- finding a black hole close enough to target and developing probes capable of withstanding the journey.

Previous knowledge on how stars evolve suggests that there could be a black hole lurking just 20 to 25 light-years from Earth, but finding it won't be easy, says Bambi. Because black holes don't emit or reflect light, they are virtually invisible to telescopes. Instead, scientists detect and study them based on how they influence nearby stars or distort light.

"There have been new techniques to discover black holes," says Bambi. "I think it's reasonable to expect we could find a nearby one within the next decade."

Once the target is identified, the next hurdle is getting there. Traditional spacecrafts, powered by chemical fuel, are too clunky and slow to make the journey. Bambi points to nanocrafts -- gram-scale probes consisting of a microchip and light sail -- as a possible solution. Earth-based lasers would blast the sail with photons, accelerating the craft to a third of the speed of light.

At that pace, the craft could reach a black hole 20 to 25 light-years away in about 70 years. The data it gathers would take another two decades to get back to Earth, making the total mission duration around 80 to 100 years.

Once the craft is near the black hole, researchers could run experiments to answer some of the most pressing questions in physics. Does a black hole truly have an event horizon, the boundary beyond which not even light can escape its gravitational pull? Do the rules of physics change near a black hole? Does Einstein's theory of general relativity hold under the universe's most extreme conditions?

Bambi notes that the lasers alone would cost around one trillion euros today, and the technology to create a nanocraft does not yet exist. But in 30 years, he says that costs may fall and technology may catch up to these bold ideas.

"It may sound really crazy, and in a sense closer to science fiction," says Bambi. "But people said we'd never detect gravitational waves because they're too weak. We did -- 100 years later. People thought we'd never observe the shadows of black holes. Now, 50 years later, we have images of two."

This work was supported by funding from the National Natural Science Foundation of China.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a visionary and inspiring scientific mission to send a tiny spacecraft to a nearby black hole, potentially rewriting physics and deepening our understanding of the universe. It highlights human ingenuity, future technological breakthroughs, and the hopeful prospect of answering fundamental questions in physics, which can uplift and inspire readers.

articles.title: Giant Einstein ring reveals one of the Universe’s biggest black holes
articles.summary: Astronomers have uncovered what may be the most massive black hole ever found, 36 billion times the mass of our Sun, hidden at the heart of the Cosmic Horseshoe galaxy. Located 5 billion light-years away, this ultramassive giant bends light into a perfect Einstein ring and whips nearby stars at incredible speeds.
articles.content:
Astronomers have discovered potentially the most massive black hole ever detected.

The cosmic behemoth is close to the theoretical upper limit of what is possible in the universe and is 10,000 times heavier than the black hole at the center of our own Milky Way galaxy.

It exists in one of the most massive galaxies ever observed - the Cosmic Horseshoe - which is so big it distorts spacetime and warps the passing light of a background galaxy into a giant horseshoe-shaped Einstein ring.

Such is the enormousness of the ultramassive black hole's size, it equates to 36 billion solar masses, according to a new paper published on August 7 in Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society.

It is thought that every galaxy in the universe has a supermassive black hole at its center and that bigger galaxies host bigger ones, known as ultramassive black holes.

"This is amongst the top 10 most massive black holes ever discovered, and quite possibly the most massive," said researcher Professor Thomas Collett, of the University of Portsmouth.

"Most of the other black hole mass measurements are indirect and have quite large uncertainties, so we really don't know for sure which is biggest. However, we've got much more certainty about the mass of this black hole thanks to our new method."

Researchers detected the Cosmic Horseshoe black hole using a combination of gravitational lensing and stellar kinematics (the study of the motion of stars within galaxies and the speed and way they move around black holes).

The latter is seen as the gold standard for measuring black hole masses, but doesn't really work outside of the very nearby universe because galaxies appear too small on the sky to resolve the region where a supermassive or ultramassive black hole lies.

Adding in gravitational lensing helped the team "push much further out into the universe," Professor Collett said.

"We detected the effect of the black hole in two ways - it is altering the path that light takes as it travels past the black hole and it is causing the stars in the inner regions of its host galaxy to move extremely quickly (almost 400 km/s).

"By combining these two measurements we can be completely confident that the black hole is real."

Lead researcher, PhD candidate Carlos Melo, of the Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS) in Brazil, added: "This discovery was made for a 'dormant' black hole - one that isn't actively accreting material at the time of observation.

"Its detection relied purely on its immense gravitational pull and the effect it has on its surroundings.

"What is particularly exciting is that this method allows us to detect and measure the mass of these hidden ultramassive black holes across the universe, even when they are completely silent."

The Cosmic Horseshoe black hole is located a long way away from Earth, at a distance of some 5 billion light-years.

"Typically, for such remote systems, black hole mass measurements are only possible when the black hole is active," Melo said. "But those accretion-based estimates often come with significant uncertainties.

"Our approach, combining strong lensing with stellar dynamics, offers a more direct and robust measurement, even for these distant systems."

The discovery is significant because it will help astronomers understand the connection between supermassive black holes and their host galaxies.

"We think the size of both is intimately linked," Professor Collett added, "because when galaxies grow they can funnel matter down onto the central black hole.

"Some of this matter grows the black hole but lots of it shines away in an incredibly bright source called a quasar. These quasars dump huge amounts of energy into their host galaxies, which stops gas clouds condensing into new stars."

Our own galaxy, the Milky Way, hosts a 4 million solar mass black hole. Currently it's not growing fast enough to blast out energy as a quasar but we know it has done in the past, and it may will do again in the future.

The Andromeda Galaxy and our Milky Way are moving together and are expected to merge in about 4.5 billion years, which is the most likely time for our supermassive black hole to become a quasar once again, the researchers say.

An interesting feature of the Cosmic Horseshoe system is that the host galaxy is a so-called fossil group.

Fossil groups are the end state of the most massive gravitationally bound structures in the universe, arising when they have collapsed down to a single extremely massive galaxy, with no bright companions.

"It is likely that all of the supermassive black holes that were originally in the companion galaxies have also now merged to form the ultramassive black hole that we have detected," said Professor Collett.

"So we're seeing the end state of galaxy formation and the end state of black hole formation."

The discovery of the Cosmic Horseshoe black hole was somewhat of a serendipitous discovery. It came about as the researchers were studying the galaxy's dark matter distribution in an attempt to learn more about the mysterious hypothetical substance.

Now that they've realized their new method works for black holes, they hope to use data from the European Space Agency's Euclid space telescope to detect more supermassive black holes and their hosts to help understand how black holes stop galaxies forming stars.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery of an ultramassive black hole using innovative methods, advancing our understanding of galaxy and black hole formation. This breakthrough is inspiring and evokes curiosity about the universe's mysteries and future research potential.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers identify one of the largest black holes using new method
articles.personality_presentation:

**What happened** – A team of astronomers discovered an ultramassive black hole in the Cosmic Horseshoe galaxy, about 5 billion light-years from Earth. This black hole is about 36 billion times the mass of our Sun, making it one of the heaviest ever found. The researchers combined two techniques: gravitational lensing, which uses the bending of light around massive objects, and stellar kinematics, studying the speed and movement of stars near the black hole. This unique combination allowed a precise measurement of the black hole’s mass, even though it is far away and currently not active.

**Impact** – This measurement is especially important because it provides strong evidence for the black hole’s size using a direct and reliable method. It shows that astronomers can now study quiet, ultramassive black holes outside our nearby cosmic neighborhood. The discovery also sheds light on how massive galaxies and black holes grow together, and it captures a late stage in galaxy evolution where several black holes have merged into one enormous object.

**What’s next step** – The researchers plan to use data from the European Space Agency’s Euclid space telescope to find and measure more distant supermassive and ultramassive black holes. This will help scientists better understand the relationship between black holes and their host galaxies, and how black holes influence star formation.

**One-sentence takeaway** – By combining light bending and star movement studies, astronomers measured one of the universe’s biggest black holes, opening a new way to explore hidden giants in distant galaxies.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des astronomes identifient l’un des plus gros trous noirs grâce à une nouvelle méthode
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques savent que la plupart des galaxies possèdent un trou noir supermassif en leur centre. Les galaxies plus grandes hébergent souvent des trous noirs encore plus massifs, appelés ultramassifs, mais il est difficile de mesurer leur masse avec précision, surtout pour les galaxies lointaines.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe d’astronomes a découvert un trou noir ultramassif dans la galaxie Cosmic Horseshoe, située à environ 5 milliards d’années-lumière de la Terre. Les chercheurs ont combiné deux techniques : la lentille gravitationnelle, qui utilise la déviation de la lumière autour des objets massifs, et la cinématique stellaire, qui étudie la vitesse et le mouvement des étoiles proches du trou noir. Cette approche unique a permis de mesurer précisément la masse du trou noir, même s’il est très éloigné et inactif.

**Impact** – Cette mesure est importante car elle fournit une preuve solide de la taille du trou noir grâce à une méthode directe et fiable. Elle montre que les astronomes peuvent désormais étudier les trous noirs ultramassifs calmes au-delà de notre voisinage cosmique. La découverte éclaire aussi la façon dont les galaxies massives et leurs trous noirs grandissent ensemble, et elle illustre une étape avancée de l’évolution galactique où plusieurs trous noirs se sont fusionnés.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs comptent utiliser les données du télescope spatial Euclid de l’Agence spatiale européenne pour détecter et mesurer davantage de trous noirs supermassifs et ultramassifs lointains. Cela aidera à mieux comprendre la relation entre les trous noirs et leurs galaxies hôtes, ainsi que leur influence sur la formation des étoiles.

**Une phrase clé** – En combinant l’étude de la déviation de la lumière et du mouvement des étoiles, les astronomes ont mesuré l’un des plus grands trous noirs de l’univers, ouvrant une nouvelle voie pour explorer ces géants cachés dans des galaxies lointaines.
articles.personality_title_es: Astrónomos identifican uno de los agujeros negros más grandes con un nuevo método
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos saben que la mayoría de las galaxias tienen agujeros negros supermasivos en su centro. Las galaxias más grandes suelen tener agujeros más grandes, llamados ultramasivos, pero medir su masa con precisión, especialmente a grandes distancias, es muy difícil.

**Qué ocurrió** – Un equipo de astrónomos descubrió un agujero negro ultramasivo en la galaxia Cosmic Horseshoe, a unos 5 mil millones de años luz de la Tierra. Este agujero negro tiene una masa de unas 36 mil millones de veces la del Sol, convirtiéndolo en uno de los más pesados jamás encontrados. Los investigadores combinaron dos técnicas: lente gravitacional, que usa la desviación de la luz alrededor de objetos masivos, y cinemática estelar, que estudia la velocidad y movimiento de estrellas cercanas al agujero negro. Esta combinación única permitió medir con precisión la masa del agujero, aunque esté muy lejos y no esté activo.

**Impacto** – Esta medición es especialmente valiosa porque ofrece una evidencia clara del tamaño del agujero negro con un método directo y confiable. Muestra que los astrónomos ahora pueden estudiar agujeros negros ultramasivos silenciosos fuera de nuestro vecindario cósmico cercano. El descubrimiento también ayuda a entender cómo crecen juntos las galaxias masivas y sus agujeros negros, y representa una etapa avanzada en la evolución de las galaxias donde varios agujeros negros se han fusionado en uno solo enorme.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean usar datos del telescopio espacial Euclid de la Agencia Espacial Europea para encontrar y medir más agujeros negros supermasivos y ultramasivos distantes. Esto ayudará a entender mejor la relación entre los agujeros negros y sus galaxias anfitrionas, y cómo influyen en la formación de estrellas.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Al combinar el estudio del desvío de la luz y el movimiento de las estrellas, los astrónomos midieron uno de los agujeros negros más grandes del universo, abriendo una nueva forma de explorar estos gigantes ocultos en galaxias lejanas.

articles.title: Meteorite that hit home is older than Earth, scientists say
articles.summary: Scientists who analysed fragments that crashed into a roof in Georgia, US, say it likely formed 4.56 billion years ago.
articles.content:
Meteorite that hit home is older than Earth, scientists say

19 hours ago Share Save Rachel Muller-Heyndyk BBC Share Save

Watch: Large fireball seen shooting across sky over Southeastern US

A meteorite that crashed into a home in the US is older than planet Earth, scientists have said. The object flew through the skies in broad daylight before exploding across the state of Georgia on 26 June, Nasa confirmed. Researchers at the University of Georgia examined a fragment of the rock that pierced the roof of a home in the city of McDonough. They found that, based on the type of meteorite, it is expected to have formed 4.56 billion years ago, making it roughly 20 million years older than Earth.

Residents in Georgia and nearby states reported hundreds of sightings and a loud booming noise when the fireball tore through the skies. The rock quickly diminished in size and speed, but still travelled at least 1 km per second, going through a man's roof in Henry County. Multiple fragments that struck the building were handed over to scientists, who analysed their origins. "This particular meteor that entered the atmosphere has a long history before it made it to the ground of McDonough," Scott Harris, a geologist at the University of Georgia, said. Using optical and electron microscopy, Harris and his team determined the rock was a chondrite - the most abundant type of stony meteorite, according to Nasa - which meant that it was approximately 4.56 billion years old.
articles.reasoning: The story reveals a fascinating scientific discovery about a meteorite older than Earth, inspiring curiosity and wonder about the universe's origins.
articles.personality_title: Meteorite older than Earth crashes into US home
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – On June 26, a bright fireball was seen across the southeastern United States as a meteorite entered the atmosphere and exploded over Georgia. Residents reported loud noises and hundreds of sightings.

**What happened** – A meteorite pierced the roof of a house in McDonough, Georgia. Scientists at the University of Georgia studied fragments collected from the site. They identified the rock as a chondrite meteorite, a common stony type, and found it formed about 4.56 billion years ago.

**Impact** – This meteorite is roughly 20 million years older than planet Earth itself. Studying such ancient space rocks helps scientists understand the early history of our solar system, including how planets and other bodies formed.

**What's next step** – Researchers will continue analyzing the meteorite fragments in detail, which may reveal more about the materials present during the solar system’s formation. This could improve knowledge about the origins of planets and life.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A meteorite that struck a Georgia home is older than Earth, offering a rare look into the very beginnings of our solar system.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une météorite plus vieille que la Terre s’écrase sur une maison aux États-Unis
articles.personality_presentation_fr:

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une météorite a traversé le toit d’une maison à McDonough, en Géorgie. Les scientifiques de l’Université de Géorgie ont étudié des fragments recueillis sur place. Ils ont identifié la roche comme une chondrite, un type de météorite pierreux courant, et ont déterminé qu’elle s’est formée il y a environ 4,56 milliards d’années.

**Impact** – Cette météorite est environ 20 millions d’années plus vieille que la planète Terre elle-même. L’étude de ces roches spatiales anciennes aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre l’histoire de notre système solaire et la formation des planètes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs continueront d’analyser les fragments en détail, ce qui pourrait révéler davantage d’informations sur les matériaux présents lors de la formation du système solaire. Cela pourrait enrichir nos connaissances sur l’origine des planètes et de la vie.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Une météorite ayant frappé une maison en Géorgie est plus vieille que la Terre, offrant un regard rare sur les débuts de notre système solaire.
